docs.lead_paragraph: RAQUEL M. GAYLE, a health care lawyer with Powell Goldstein, a law firm in Atlanta, doesn't often think about preparing for retirement, she said, mainly because she is saving half her paycheck to buy a house. She is, after all, 33 and single, with a $130,000 annual salary. But fear does strike at times, in the guise of a representative from Northwestern Mutual who occasionally tries to encourage Ms. Gayle and her colleagues to invest in term life insurance as a way to save for retirement. ''We hide from him, stand him up at Starbucks because of the scary numbers he puts before us,'' Ms. Gayle said.

headline.main: The Future? Let's Not Talk About It

docs.abstract: Atlanta lawyer Raquel M Gayle, 33, discusses her hope of saving for retirement; photo (special section, Retirement) (S)
docs.snippet: RAQUEL M. GAYLE, a health care lawyer with Powell Goldstein, a law firm in Atlanta, doesn't often think about preparing for retirement, she said, mainly because she is saving half her paycheck to buy a house. She is, after all, 33 and single, with a...

docs.lead_paragraph: SIXTEEN years ago, a small-scale study of human growth hormone therapy among older men opened a large debate in the medical community over whether it could stave off physical decline. Since then, the arguments on both sides have become only more passionate. Demands for prescriptions have increased, as has online demand for both legitimate and fraudulent forms of the product, known as HGH -- eventually growing into an estimated $1 billion global market.

headline.main: Growth Hormone: The Secret of Youth or a Cautionary Tale?

docs.abstract: Demand for human growth hormoneas anti-aging product stirs concern among some doctors because of potentially harmful side-effects; geriatrician Dr Robert N Butler warns of experimentation with unsuspecting people and says that nutrition and exercise will yield equal or better results in building muscle mass and increasing well-being; Dr Eric Braverman is among doctors defending use of HGH at low, carefully supervised levels (special section, Retirement)
docs.snippet: SIXTEEN years ago, a small-scale study of human growth hormone therapy among older men opened a large debate in the medical community over whether it could stave off physical decline.     Since then, the arguments on both sides have become only more...

docs.lead_paragraph: WHEN Verizon Communications decided to close down Douglas S. Burch's department, nudging him into early retirement after 27 years on the job, he had no complaints. ''I decided to take the money and run,'' said Mr. Burch, 54, a software designer. He renovated his home in Alexandria, Va. But after two years, he said, ''I was getting bored.''
docs.abstract: Senior Employment Resources in Annandale, Va, is one of many agencies for older adults seeking temporary or permanent jobs; photo; BLS data show 16.4 percent of US workers, more than 40 million people, were 55 or older in 2005,figure that will rise to twenty percent by 2015 (special section, Retirement) (M)
docs.snippet: The demand for work by those approaching retirement age is so great that employment services specializing in the over-50 age group are cropping up.

docs.lead_paragraph: Wal-Mart Stores arrived here Monday with a reassuring message for banking regulators: it promises that it will never, ever open bank branches. That pledge could prove crucial for Wal-Mart, whose banking ambitions have sparked considerable protest and prompted the first public hearing in the 73-year history of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, which would regulate a Wal-Mart bank.

headline.main: Wal-Mart Promises To Limit Its Banking

docs.snippet: In testimony before federal banking regulators, Wal-Mart repeated its message over and over again: the company will not open bank branches.

docs.lead_paragraph: The White House is clashing with the nation's largest employers over their request for huge amounts of government data on the cost and quality of health care provided by doctors around the country. President Bush has repeatedly urged private insurers to disclose such data, saying it will help consumers choose doctors and hospitals. But Medicare, the nation's largest insurer, has turned down a request for its data from the Business Roundtable, whose member companies provide coverage to more than 25 million people.

headline.main: Employers Push White House to Disclose Medicare Data

docs.abstract: Bush administration is resisting call by nation's largest employers to disclose information about cost and quality of health care provided by doctors nationwide; Medicare has turned down request for information; employers want to use data to compare and rate doctors, thus reining in health care costs; administration says it shares goals, but is constrained by court ruling that limits disclosure of data showing Medicare payments to individual doctors; employers say ruling is no longer relevant (M)
docs.snippet: The nation's largest employers say data on the cost and quality of care provided by doctors around the country would help rein in their health insurance costs.

docs.lead_paragraph: THERE'S a checklist for people in their mid-50's who are thinking about the new retirement, the one that starts before 65 and means still working, but in a more appealing job, for shorter hours or for yourself: kids through college? Check. Marketable skills? Check. Enough in the bank to make up for a step-down in pay? Check. Now add one more item: a total of $50,000 to $100,000, or in some cases more, to cover health insurance until you qualify for Medicare -- assuming you are healthy enough to qualify for insurance at all.

headline.main: Want to Retire Early and Hang a Shingle? It'll Cost You

docs.abstract: Economists warn that evaporation of health benefits for younger retirees will play important role in final career trajectory of baby boom generation, perhaps determining whether next decade sees outpouring of new ventures or office cubicles clogged with workers waiting for Medicare; graph showing decline percentage of private-sector employers offering health insurance to retirees (special section, Retirement)
docs.snippet: The evaporation of health benefits for younger retirees will play an important role in the final career trajectory of the baby boom generation, economists say.

docs.lead_paragraph: MIGRATORY retirees have lent more than a touch of gray to Florida, Arizona and Southern California. Next stop on the aging boomer bandwagon: Panama. With low housing and living costs, a stable political environment, relatively safe streets and that tropical climate, people in their 50's and early 60's are flocking to the Central American nation, rather than working for a few more years to scrape together enough money for a condo on the Florida coast.

headline.main: Content to Watch Bananas Grow, More Retirees Relocate to Panama

docs.abstract: Older Americans who have retired to Panama discuss lifestyle and lower living costs there; photo (special section, Retirement) (M)
docs.snippet: Migratory retirees have lent more than a touch of gray to Florida, Arizona and Southern California. Next stop on the aging boomer bandwagon: Panama.

multimedia.caption: Panama Today
multimedia.credit: Will Panama go the way of Costa Rica? Or will the commerce win out.

legacy.MultimediaSummary1: Will Panama go the way of Costa Rica? Or will the commerce win out.

docs.lead_paragraph: Mark Green, a candidate for attorney general, is calling for stricter laws to deter abuses by health maintenance organizations in New York State, as well as more aggressive prosecution of violators. Mr. Green, who served as New York City public advocate for eight years, is to outline his recommendations at a speech today at Baruch College. The speech is the first in a series of presentations he plans to give on public policy issues over the course of the campaign.

headline.main: Green Urges Stricter Laws To Deter Abuses by H.M.O.'s

docs.abstract: New York State candidate for attorney general, Mark Green, calls for stricter laws to deter abuses by health maintenance organizations and more aggressive prosecution of violators (M)
docs.snippet: Mark Green, a candidate for attorney general, is calling for stricter laws to deter abuses by health maintenance organizations in New York State, as well as more aggressive prosecution of violators.
